Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: From the Lab to the Ocean: Experimental modeling of Internal Tide Generation by Topography
Award.AbstractNarration:
OCE-0645529
Intellectual merit: Internal-wave generation in the deep ocean is currently a very active research topic because of the recent recognition of its important role in deep-ocean mixing. The intellectual merit of the work is in the laboratory investigation of outstanding, fundamental issues regarding internal-wave generation by deep-ocean bathymetry, for which there is a significant absence of experimental data. Although lab-scale, the proposed experiments are directly relevant to ocean processes. The outstanding issues addressed in study are the modal composition, energy-flux and instabilities of internal tides from 2D and 3D bathymetry. This timely investigation will expand current observational, numerical and theoretical understanding of internal-wave generation through sophisticated laboratory experiments. The experiments will generate detailed spatiotemporal data in regimes that are not amenable to current theoretical and numerical models, and for which field studies can inevitably provide only sparse data in uncontrolled environments. This research will also develop synergistic numerical modeling of the experiments.

Broader impact: Internal waves impact the Earth's climate and modern-day underwater technology. Future theoretical and numerical models that have been validated by our benchmark data, made available through a website, will enhance our ability to predict the environmental and technological impact of internal waves. A new partnership between MIT and UCLA will be established that will be instrumental for the development of a non-hydrostatic ROMS model, which has promise to become a next-generation community ocean model. Through this new partnership and involvement in ocean-going research, the CAREER award will facilitate fruitful collaboration of scientific groups with different backgrounds, encouraging exchange of ideas and methodologies. The PI has included letters of collaboration from Prof. McWilliams and Assistant Prof. Alford to attest to the utility and excitement generated by the experimental results. The PI will use his state-of-the-art experimental facilities for hands-on teaching of K-12, undergraduate and graduate students. High-school and undergraduate students will perform experiments integrated with the CAREER research goals; with assessment provided by educators at MIT. A new graduate-course module on internal tides will be developed, and two Ph.D. students in the MIT-Woods Hole Joint Program, one a female, minority student, will be trained in laboratory and ocean-going research. The PI will participate in a summer program for science educators, for which he will organize sessions on ocean science. Letters of collaboration from the Center for Ocean Sciences Education Excellence, the Research Science Institute, the MIT-Woods Hole Joint Program and the Science and Engineering Program for Teachers testify their commitment to supporting the PI's education plan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internal tides, which are waves in the ocean density stratification with oscillation periods of half-a-day and a day, driven by the tides, play a crucial role in the dynamics of the oceans because the huge amounts of energy they transport underly important mixing processes. Due to the complex distribution of internal tide generation sites throughout the oceans, these being large scale ocean ridges such as the Hawaiian Island Chain, it has been a challenge to both reliably calculate the total global energy flux budget for internal tides and to reliably predict where and how the internal tide wave fields become unstable and produce mixing.

This project used advanced laboratory methods to investigate the nature of internal tide generation by large-scale flow over ocean-ridge topography. In parallel, a new theoretical model of internal tide generation, called iTides, was developed and made freely available for use by oceanographers to assist in the planning of field studies and the interpretation of data from field measurements and numerical models. The iTides model was validated by the laboratory experiments, which furthermore showed that the iTides model can work well even in very demanding regimes, where the wave dynamics becomes highly complex. A sample of the internal wave field associated with a 2000m tall ocean ridge in a 3500m deep ocean, as calculated using iTides, is shown in the first attached figure; the quantity plotted is the horizontal velocity. The second attached figure shows a comparison between the internal tides generated in a laboratory experiment, using iTides, and by a full numerical model run by a collaborator.

As a result of this project, as well as having an efficient and proven tool for studying internal tide generation, we now have a more confident grasp on the energy flux into internal tides by large-scale ocean ridges. Furthermore, we now have a clearer understanding of the nature of the wave fields produced, enhancing our ability to predict where and how internal tides can become unstable and drive mixing, which in turn impacts our ability to make reliable climate predictions using large scale numerical models. 

There were several other significant outcomes of this project. Two graduate students received their Ph.D. and several graduate and undergraduate students had the opportunity to participate in ocean research cruises studying internal tides. The attached photo shows the PI and his student, Paula Echeverri, testing their survival suits aboard the RV Revelle during the NSF funded IWAP research cruise. Two major workshops on internal tides were held in Banff, Canada and Les Houches, France, drawing experts from around the world, and a workshop on Climate was held at MIT for K-12 educators.

In addition to the proposed internal tide research, the events of the Deep Water Horizon oil spill in 2010 prompted investigation of an additional research avenue known as Lagrangian Coherent Structures (LCSs). LCSs are the hidden skeleton of flow transport in complex ocean flows and the ability to identify them and understand their evolution provides us with a new tool for dealing with important decision making strategies for the ocean, such as coordingating the response to an oil spill, as well as for enhancing our understanding of natural phenomena, such as the formation of algal blooms. We have developed and advanced the LCS methodology, and applied the analysis methods to regions as diverse as the Gulf of Mexico, Gulf of Alaska and the West Coast of Australia, identifying key and persistent transport features for each of these regions. This gives oceanographers the ability to better understand natural processes in these regions and to develop emergency response plans in the event of accidents.
